Efficient oxidation of phenol by persulfate using manganite as a catalyst Yang Li a Lin-Dong Liu b Lu Liu a Ying Liu a Hong-Wei Zhang a Xu Han c d ⁎ a School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Tianjin Polytechnic University, Tianjin, PR China School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering Tianjin Polytechnic University Tianjin PR China b Key Laboratory of Advanced Textile Composites, Ministry of Education, Tianjin Polytechnic University, Tianjin, PR China Key Laboratory of Advanced Textile Composites Ministry of Education Tianjin Polytechnic University Tianjin PR China c School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin, PR China School of Environmental Science and Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin PR China d Key Laboratory of Systems Bioengineering, Ministry of Education, Tianjin University, Tianjin, PR China Key Laboratory of Systems Bioengineering Ministry of Education Tianjin University Tianjin PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin, PR China. Graphical abstract In this study, three trivalent Mn (oxyhydr)oxides, bixbyite (α-Mn2O3), hausmannite (Mn3O4) and manganite (γ-MnOOH) were synthesized and used as persulfate (PS) activators in phenol oxidation. Of these three Mn (oxyhydr)oxides, only γ-MnOOH shows a good catalytic activity in PS activation with more than 80% phenol oxidized within 360min in the full pH range. With increasing concentrations of PS and γ-MnOOH, phenol removal efficiency increased. TOC results also suggest that phenol oxidation at pH 11 is more complete than those at pH 7 and 3. We further confirm that mechanism involved in phenol oxidation is pH dependent in γ-MnOOH/PS system. Although SO4 − and OH were both found under acidic and alkaline conditions, they did not contribute equally under different pHs. At pH 11, SO4 − and OH generated from PS activation efficiently oxidize phenol. At pH 3, the strong oxidation activity of γ-MnOOH and an oxidative intermediate formed between S2O8 2− and γ-MnOOH primarily contribute to phenol oxidation. At pH 7, an oxidative intermediate formed between γ-MnOOH and S2O8 2− is the predominant oxidative species in phenol oxidation. Keywords Persulfate γ-MnOOH Phenol oxidation EPR spectra 1 Introduction Toxic phenolic compounds are extensively used in pesticides, petroleum refining, textile and paper industries, which cause threats to the aqueous environments [1–3]. Compared with conventional methods in the treatment of phenolic wastewater, advanced oxidation progresses (AOPs) such as Fenton or Fenton-like reactions, which always generate hydroxyl radical (OH) or superoxide (O2 − ) radicals from H2O2, can effectively oxidize organic contaminants to CO2 and H2O [4–8]. However, these reactions are always constrained by pH limitations, and oxidation activity decreases rapidly as pH increases above 5.0 [9]. In order to broaden the application of AOPs in the full pH range, more interests have been paid to in situ chemical oxidation (ISCO). Recently, peroxymonosulfate (Oxone, PMS) and persulfate (PS) have attracted more attention due to their high yields of sulfate radicals (SO4 −, E 0 =2.5–3.1V) [10], which show higher oxidation activities than OH (E 0 =1.8–2.7V) [11]. Although PS is always thought to be less reactive than PMS, its price is more cost-effective ($0.74 per kg) compared with PMS ($2.2 per kg) and hydrogen peroxide ($1.5 per kg) [12], suggesting the more economical of this oxidant in scale-up applications. (1) S 2 O 8 2 − + initiator → SO 4 − + ( SO 4 − or SO 4 2 − ) PS can be activated readily via different pathways (Eq. (1)). Previous study has demonstrated that Ag(I) was the best homogeneous catalyst among nine transition metal ions to activate PMS and PS at pH 3, and Co(II) and Ru(III) could effectively activate PMS at pH 7 [13]. However, due to the high cost and toxicity of these metal ions, as well as their unrecyclable properties and pH limitations, interests have been transferred increasingly to heterogeneous catalysts such as metal oxides [14–16]. Manganese (oxyhydr)oxides with diverse valence states, such as divalent (II, MnO), trivalent (III, Mn2O3, MnOOH) and tetravalent (IV, MnO2), abundantly exist in nature. Their cost-effective and environmental friendly properties make them good candidates in PMS activation. For instance, α-Mn2O3 shows a best activity in PMS activation among MnO, MnO2, Mn2O3 and Mn3O4, with 75% of 100mgL−1 phenol removed in 120min [17]. MnO2 with different crystalline structure (α-, β- and γ-) also shows good performances in PMS activation, and 25mgL−1 phenol could be completely degraded in α-MnO2-PMS system in 20min [18]. To the best of our knowledge, Mn(III) (oxyhydr)oxides such as α-Mn2O3 and Mn3O4, especially manganite (γ-MnOOH), which is composed of Mn(III)-O6, have not been used for PS activation. Mn(III)-O6 is similar to Fe(III)-O6 octahedra, and can be edge- and corner-shared to form manganite, which has a 1×1 tunnel where hydrogen atoms reside [19]. In addition, manganite and feitknechtite (β-MnOOH) can also directly oxidize organic pollutants such as phenol, a process of which is favored when pH is below 4.0 [20]. Two pathways involved in PS decomposition have been proposed: Under acidic and neutral conditions, 1 PS is heterolytically decomposed into 1 SO4 − and 1 SO4 2− during the activation process (Eqs. (2) and (3)), followed by OH generation via the reaction of SO4 − and H2O (Eq. (4)) [21]. Under alkaline condition, 1 PS is decomposed homolytically into 2 SO4 − radicals, the latter of which are then transformed to OH (Eqs. (5) and (6)) [22,23]; whereas some studies believed that PS was first transformed to PMS, the latter of which was then decomposed to sulfate and molecular oxygen [23,24]. Acidic conditions: (2) S 2 O 8 2 − + H + → HS 2 O 8 − (3) HS 2 O 8 − → SO 4 − + S O 4 2 − + H + (4) SO 4 − + H 2 O → HSO 4 − + OH Alkaline conditions: (5) S 2 O 8 2 − → 2 S O 4 − (6) SO 4 − + OH − → S O 4 2 − + OH In this study, three Mn(III) (oxyhydr)oxides including α-Mn2O3, Mn3O4 and γ-MnOOH, will be evaluated for their catalytic abilities in PS activation under different pH conditions. Reactive species involved in phenol degradation will be determined, and possible mechanisms involved in PS activation will be proposed afterwards. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials MnSO4∙H2O was obtained from Tianjin Feng Chuan Chemical Co., Ltd. Phenol, sodium hydroxide, 38% HCl, 25% NH3∙H2O and 30% H2O2 were obtained from Tianjin Bei Fang Chemical Co. Ltd. Potassium persulfate was purchased from Tianjin Guang Fu Chemical Co., Ltd. 5,5-Dimethyl-1-pyrroline (DMPO, >99.0%) was obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Industrial Co. Ltd. All chemicals were not further purified, and all solution was prepared with deionized water. 2.2 Methods γ-MnOOH was synthesized according to Giovanoli [25] by adding 300mL of 0.2M NH3∙H2O into the mixture of 20.4mL 30% H2O2 and 1L of 0.06M MnSO4∙4H2O. The mixture was quickly stirred and heated at 95°C for 6h. After that, the suspension was centrifuged, and the separated particles were washed with hot deionized water four times to remove soluble impurities. The sediment was then freeze-dried, grinded and stored under vacuum. α-Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 were synthesized by calcining the manganite at 650°C for 8h and at 1000°C for 10h, respectively, in muffle furnace under air conditions with the temperature rising at a speed of 10°C/min [26]. 2.3 Catalytic activity of Mn (oxyhydr)oxides Measured amounts of Mn (oxyhydr)oxides were equilibrated in 105mL deionized water of a 250mL light-tight flask for 4h in a shaker with a speed of 150rpm, and pHs were adjusted to defined values by using 1M HCl or NaOH during equilibration. After that, 30mL PS stock solution and 15mL phenol stock solution were mixed with Mn (oxyhydr)oxides suspension with identical pHs. Reaction was initiated by the addition of phenol, and initial concentrations of Mn (oxyhydr)oxides, PS and phenol were 1gL−1, 2gL−1 and 100mgL−1, respectively. Samples were taken out at regular intervals and centrifuged at 12,000rpm for 4min. The supernatant was then used for the analysis of phenol and TOC, as well as UV–vis full wavelength scanning. Catalyst reusability was tested in three cycles, and the used catalyst was centrifuged and washed with deionized water before it was used in the next run. All experiments were carried out in duplicate at 20°C and conducted in the dark in order to prevent photochemical reactions. 2.4 Analysis and characterization Crystalline structure of three different synthetic Mn (oxyhydr)oxides was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku, D/max-2200/PC) with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5406Å). Samples were scanned from 2θ =10–90° with a 2θ =0.02° step-size. Morphology of the synthetic products was examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100F, JEOL). Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR, Nicolet 670, Thermo Fisher Scientific) were collected on a Thermo Nicolet Nexus FTIR spectrometer via a KBr pressed disk method to identify functional groups on these three Mn (oxyhydr)oxides. Phenol and sulfate concentrations were measured by 4-aminoantipyrine spectrophotometry method and BaCl2 turbidimetrical method, respectively [27]. Total organic carbon (TOC) was measured with a Shimadzu TOC-5000 analyzer. UV–vis full wavelength scanning was conducted with a Shimadzu UV-2050 analyzer to identify variation of intermediates in solution. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR, Bruker, EMX-6/1) was also used to detect possible free radicals generated during PS activation. PS residuals were analyzed by the iodometric method [28]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of Mn (oxyhydr)oxides Crystalline structure of the synthesized samples was determined by XRD. Diffraction peaks of the three manganese oxides are in accordance with characteristic peaks of bixbyite (α-Mn2O3, JCPDS, 65–7467), hausmannite (Mn3O4, JCPDS, 24–0734), and manganite (γ-MnOOH, JCPDS, 41–1379) (Fig. 1 ). Morphology analysis indicates that nanostructured α-Mn2O3, Mn3O4 and γ-MnOOH is rhombic, hexagonal and nanorods, respectively (Fig. 2 a–c). FTIR analysis further suggests that 1084, 1115 and 1150cm−1 are characteristic peaks of γ-MnOOH, representing γ-OH, δ-2-OH and δ-1-OH bending modes [29] (Fig. S1). The peak at 2600–2700cm−1 is the characteristic OH stretching band, which is associated with the hydrogen band of OH⋯O in the structure of γ-MnOOH [29]. The peaks below 601cm−1 mainly represent MnO vibrations. When γ-MnOOH was calcinated above 250°C, OH chemical bonds at 1000–3000cm−1 gradually disappeared, with only the Mn-O chemical band remained (Fig. S1). When the temperature was raised 650 and 1000°C, γ-MnOOH was degraded into α-Mn2O3 and Mn3O4, respectively, with the appearance of characteristic peaks at 574 and 524cm−1 for α-Mn2O3, and 637,533 and 424cm−1 for Mn3O4 [26]. 3.2 Catalytic activity of three Mn (oxyhydr)oxides In order to make a comparison, adsorption and oxidation of phenol on three Mn (oxyhydr)oxides in the absence of PS was conducted. More than 20%, 40% and 50% phenol was removed (including adsorption and oxidation) by α-Mn2O3, Mn3O4 and γ-MnOOH, respectively after 24h at pH 3, whereas less than 15% phenol was removed by these Mn (oxyhydr)oxides under neutral and alkaline conditions (Fig. S2). This suggests that phenol can be oxidized by Mn (oxyhydr)oxides under acidic conditions. Previous studies also mentioned that organic contaminants such as phenol, chlorophene and nitrilotrismethylenephosphonic acid could be oxidized by Mn(III) (oxyhydr)oxides under acidic conditions [20,30,31]. Oxidation of phenolic compounds with PS in the absence of Mn (oxyhydr)oxides also shows that less than 5% phenol was degraded after 24h, implying that phenol cannot be readily oxidized by PS in the absence of catalysts (Fig. S2). On the other hand, phenol removal can be significantly accelerated in the presence of MnO x and PS. Fig. 3 a shows that phenol removal efficiency increased from 59.79%, 45.2% and 5.27% to 72.66%, 54.81% and 19.86% as for γ-MnOOH, α-Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 systems, respectively under acidic conditions. Under pH neutral and alkaline conditions, only γ-MnOOH can effectively catalyze phenol removal, and the phenol removal percentages increased rapidly to 91.86% and 96.28% as for pH 7 and 11, respectively after 360min, whereas removal efficiencies in α-Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 systems were negligible (Fig. 3b and c). In addition, it is noticed that γ-MnOOH shows better catalytic activities under neutral and alkaline conditions than that under acidic conditions, given that Mn2+ leaching from γ-MnOOH under acidic condition reduces reactive sites on γ-MnOOH [20]. After the oxidation progresses, γ-MnOOH still maintained rod-like morphology, with the appearance of some round particles at pH 3 (Fig. 2d), suggesting formation of other Mn (oxyhydr)oxides. However, these round particles cannot be confirmed by XRD analysis due to their small amount or amorphous properties (data not shown). At pH 7 and 11, rod-like γ-MnOOH agglomerated together, which reduced active sites for phenol oxidation (Fig. 2e and f). In consideration of different crystalline structure of MnOOH, which may lead to different results for the removal of phenol, β-MnOOH was also used for phenol removal. Phenol can be slightly removed by β-MnOOH in the absence or presence of PS under pH 3, whereas phenol removal was negligible under pH 7 and 11 (Fig. S3), suggesting catalytic activity is also dependent on crystalline structure. The effect of γ-MnOOH dosage on phenol removal was also investigated, and 0.25–1gL−1 γ-MnOOH was used. Phenol removal was highly enhanced with increasing γ-MnOOH dosages. At pH 3 and 0.25gL−1 γ-MnOOH, only 33% phenol was removed in 360min, whereas more than 80% phenol was wiped off when γ-MnOOH was 1gL−1 (Fig. 4 a). Similar observations can be found at pH 7 and 11 (Fig. 4b and c). PS concentration on phenol removal by γ-MnOOH was also investigated, and the results show that 30.99%, 69.78%, 95.51% and 98.2% phenol was removed with initial concentrations of PS from 0.5 to 4gL−1 at pH 11, respectively, and phenol removal was more sensitive to PS concentration under alkaline conditions (Fig. 5 ). Given that inorganic anions (nitrate and sulfate) are commonly found in phenol-contained industrial wastewaters, such anions were tested in phenol oxidation. Sulfate and nitrate showed negative effects on phenol removal in a full pH range, and phenol removal decreased with increasing anion concentrations, with only 30–40% and 60% phenol removed in sulfate systems and nitrate systems, respectively (Fig. S4). This is in accordance with previous studies that sulfate and nitrate showed inhibitory effects on PS activation [32,33]. UV analysis was conducted to provide useful information on the variation of intermediates during phenol oxidation. The slow disappearance of phenolic hydroxyl group at 270nm indicates a complete removal of phenol (Fig. S5) [34]. The shift of phenolic hydroxyl group at pH 11 was as a result of pH change during the oxidation process (Fig. S5c). TOC results also show that 79.34%, 97.02%, and 97.12% TOC was removed at pH 3, 7 and 11, respectively after 360min (Fig. 6 ), which further suggests a more complete oxidation of phenol under pH neutral and alkaline conditions. During the recycling experiments, the catalytic activity of manganite under neutral and alkaline condition was slightly decreased in three cycles’ evaluation. At pH 7, 74.27% and 57.5% phenol was removed in the 2nd and 3rd cycles, respectively, whereas at pH 11, 83.12% and 69.16% phenol was removed, respectively (Fig. 7 ). Previous study also mentioned that adsorption of intermediates from phenol degradation on the surface of catalysts inhibited further oxidation of phenol [35]. How to improve the reusability of manganite is important for its further applications. 3.3 Mechanisms involved in phenol oxidation by γ-MnOOH and PS Previous studies have reported that SO4 − radicals produced from PS activated by transition metal oxides could strongly oxidize organics [36–38]. Scavenger experiments were carried out to confirm oxidative radicals involved in phenol oxidation. Tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) is an effective scavenger for OH (k =6.0×108 M−1 s−1) [10,39] but not for SO4 − (k =8.0×105 M−1 s−1) [11,39], whereas methanol can effectively scavenge both SO4 − (k =2.5×107 M−1 s−1) [10,40] and OH (k =9.7×108 M−1 s−1) [11,40]. This allows us to differentiate contribution of SO4 − and OH in phenol oxidation. At pH 3, phenol removal was not obviously inhibited by TBA and methanol (Fig. 8 a), which suggests that neither SO4 − nor OH was the predominant oxidative species. Given that γ-MnOOH showed a strong oxidation activity at pH 3 and could effectively oxidize ca. 60% phenol in the absence of PS in 6h (Fig. S2a), an oxidative intermediate formed between S2O8 2− and γ-MnOOH should partially contribute to phenol oxidation. At pH 7, 1M methanol or TBA slightly inhibited phenol oxidation (Fig. 8b), suggesting that SO4 − and OH were not the predominant oxidative species. On the other hand, we can notice that phenol oxidation is always less than 20% by either PS or γ-MnOOH alone (Fig. S2b). This implies that other oxidative species should be involved in oxidation process at pH 7. It therefore can be assumed that an oxidative intermediate formed between S2O8 2− and γ-MnOOH effectively oxidized phenol at pH 7. Previous study mentioned that apart from generating SO4 − and OH radicals, PS could also form an outer-sphere complex with CuO, which then efficiently oxidized organic contaminants [41]. Fig. 8c shows that methanol and TBA significantly inhibited phenol oxidation at pH 11, and the removal efficiency of phenol decreased from 95% to 10% with the addition of 1M methanol or TBA. This suggests that the generated SO4 − and OH played important roles in phenol oxidation at pH 11. In order to better understand the mechanisms involved in phenol oxidation by γ-MnOOH and PS, EPR spectra was introduced to identify possible radicals produced in this process. DMPO (5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline) was used to trap the generated free radicals, and the signals of DMPO-SO4 − and DMPO-HO can be observed during the process [42]. PS can be effectively activated at pH 11 by γ-MnOOH to produce SO4 − and OH radicals (Fig. 9 a), the latter of which was generated from the reactions between SO4 − and OH− (Eq. (6)). Under acidic conditions, given the instability of γ-MnOOH, Mn2+ was detected. Apart from Mn2+, SO4 − and OH are also found in Fig. S6b, which can be attributed to PS activation by Mn2+ or γ-MnOOH (Eq. (7)). In order to investigate catalytic effect of the released Mn(II) from manganite on phenol oxidation, supernatant from γ-MnOOH solution was mixed with PS and phenol at pH 3.0. Fig. S7 shows that contribution of the released Mn(II) from manganite was negligible in phenol removal. Previous study also demonstrated that Mn2+ could not effectively catalyze oxidation of 2, 4-dichlorophenol by PS [13]. In addition, we also notice that γ-MnOOH after reacting with phenol still maintained its morphology in the full pH range (Fig. 2d–f). The changes of PS concentration were also recorded by iodometric method. Fig. S8 shows that less than 25% PS was decomposed at pH 3 in 360min, and sulfate ions concentration were generated continuously as PS decomposed. At pH 7 and 11, decomposition rates of PS and generation rates of sulfate were significantly enhanced (Fig. S8), suggesting that more PS was utilized for phenol oxidation. The above results suggest that γ-MnOOH is a good catalyst for PS activation in phenol oxidation, and the oxidation mechanism depends on pH conditions. Under alkaline condition, PS is activated to SO4 − and OH radicals, which then effectively oxidize phenol contaminants (Eqs. (5)–(8)). Under acidic and neutral conditions, although PS can be activated and produce SO4 − and OH radicals (Eq. (7)), these radicals are not the prominent oxidative species, and an oxidative intermediate formed between γ-MnOOH and S2O8 2− may play important roles in phenol oxidation under pH neutral condition (Eqs. (9) and (10)). The strong oxidation activity of γ-MnOOH is primarily responsible for phenol oxidation under acidic condition (Eq. (11)). (7) S 2 O 8 2 − γ − MnOOH / M n 2 + → S O 4 − + S O 4 2 − + OH − (8) C 6 H 5 OH + SO 4 − ( OH ) → intermediates → CO 2 + H 2 O + S O 4 2 − + H + (9) ≡ Mn ( III ) + − OSOOSO − 3 3 → ≡ Mn ( III ) − − OSOOSO 3 − 3 (10) ≡ Mn ( III ) + − OSOOSO 3 − 3 + C 6 H 5 OH → intermediates → CO 2 + H 2 O + H + + SO 4 − 2 (11) γ − MnOOH + C 6 H 5 OH → Mn ( II ) + H + + intermediate s → CO 2 + H 2 O 4 Conclusion In this study, three synthetic Mn (oxyhydr)oxides of α-Mn2O3, Mn3O4 and γ-MnOOH, were used for PS activation and applied in phenol oxidation. γ-MnOOH showed the best performance in the full pH range, and phenol removal efficiency at pH 11 was better than those at pH 3 and 7. At pH 3, only 80% phenol was removed, whereas the removal of phenol could be more than 90% and 95% at pH 7 and 11, respectively. Mechanisms involved in catalytic oxidation of phenol by PS and γ-MnOOH depend on pH conditions. At pH 11, EPR spectra and quenching experiments suggest that SO4 − and OH generated during PS activation efficiently oxidized phenol. Although SO4 − and OH were also detected at pH 3, they did not play important roles in phenol oxidation. Actually, the strong oxidation activity of γ-MnOOH at pH 3 and an oxidative intermediate formed between S2O8 2− and γ-MnOOH primarily contribute to phenol oxidation. At pH 7, an oxidative intermediate formed between γ-MnOOH and S2O8 2− may be the predominant oxidative species in phenol oxidation. This study enriches our understandings on the catalytic activities of Mn (oxyhydr)oxides during PS activation, as well as pH-dependent mechanisms involved in phenol oxidation. We also suggest that future work should be done to further identify the possible oxidative species formed under acidic and neutral conditions. Acknowledgments We greatly acknowledge the financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 41373114; No. 41201487; No.51308390), the Natural Science Foundation of Tianjin (No. 15JCZDJC40200), and the Open Funding Project of the Key Laboratory of Systems Bioengineering, Ministry of Education. We also thank the technical assistance of EPR analysis from Mr. YU Au from Nankai University. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2015.10.036. coredata.dc:description: In this study, three trivalent Mn (oxyhydr)oxides, bixbyite (α-Mn2O3), hausmannite (Mn3O4) and manganite (γ-MnOOH) were synthesized and used as persulfate (PS) activators in phenol oxidation. Of these three Mn (oxyhydr)oxides, only γ-MnOOH shows a good catalytic activity in PS activation with more than 80% phenol oxidized within 360min in the full pH range. With increasing concentrations of PS and γ-MnOOH, phenol removal efficiency increased. TOC results also suggest that phenol oxidation at pH 11 is more complete than those at pH 7 and 3. We further confirm that mechanism involved in phenol oxidation is pH dependent in γ-MnOOH/PS system. Although SO4 − and OH were both found under acidic and alkaline conditions, they did not contribute equally under different pHs. At pH 11, SO4 − and OH generated from PS activation efficiently oxidize phenol. At pH 3, the strong oxidation activity of γ-MnOOH and an oxidative intermediate formed between S2O8 2− and γ-MnOOH primarily contribute to phenol oxidation. At pH 7, an oxidative intermediate formed between γ-MnOOH and S2O8 2− is the predominant oxidative species in phenol oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient oxidation of phenol by persulfate using manganite as a catalyst
